item.title: King Charles breaks major Royal tradition in 2024 Christmas message
item.dc:creator: Saoirse Hammond
item.description: King Charles has broken a classic Royal tradition in his 2024 Christmas message to the nation. The 76-year-old monarch recorded his annual speech in a special location outside of a royal residence for the first time in over a decade. Today's top videos King Charles recorded his speech at the Fitzrovia Chapel, a former hospital […]
item.content:encoded:
King Charles has broken a classic Royal tradition in his 2024 Christmas message to the nation.

The 76-year-old monarch recorded his annual speech in a special location outside of a royal residence for the first time in over a decade.

Today's top videos

King Charles recorded his speech at the Fitzrovia Chapel, a former hospital chapel in Pearson Square, central London, almost two weeks ago, according to reports.

A still image from the unseen video shows the King smiling at the camera as he stands in front of a beautiful Christmas tree, decorated with pinecones, metal bells, and twisted glass and, baubles.

The monarch's choice of venue reflects his strong Christian beliefs and various health struggles he and other members of his family have faced this year.

This year's message from the King is reportedly going to focus on international, national and personal challenges and how they support from one another will help overcome tough times.

The Princess of Wales also picked a similar theme for her Christmas carol concert, which focused on the importance of kindness, love, and empathy.

Against the beautiful backdrop of Fitzrovia Chapel, the King is set to thank the incredible work of the healthcare professionals, especially in light of the riots and the Southport stabbings this summer.

It is understood that Charles' decision to film outside of Buckingham Palace or Windsor Castle was to give it a more modern feel.

The Fitzrovia Chapel, described on its website as 'an enchanting jewel of Byzantine inspired architecture,' the first mass was held in the chapel on Christmas Day 1891 and it quickly became a place for both staff and patients of the former Middlesex Hospital to reflect and find solace.

The fact that this was a non-denominational chapel is also said to have been a key factor in picking it, a reflection of the King's respect to all faiths, not just Christianty.

The chapel remains a place of worship today, and is also used for weddings and civil partnerships, community events, concerts, and fashion shows.

The last Christmas broadcast not recorded at a royal residence was one by the late Queen's at Hampton Court Palace in 2010.

In 2003, Elizabeth II also opted to speak from the Household Cavalry Barracks in Windsor because she wanted to draw attention to the many members of servicemen and women who were deployed overseas.

King Charles delivered his first Christmas message as monarch from St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle in 2022 and from Buckingham Palace in 2023.

Cadbury is no longer 'sweet' with the Royal family as King Charles makes drastic change

item.title: This chic beauty look will be one of 2025's biggest makeup trends
item.dc:creator: Laura Bermingham
item.description: What makeup trends will 2025 bring our way? We ae seeing lots of indications that a new version of 'skinification' will be in demand, a new and glowy minimalist approach to foundation. Lived-in eye liner is also looking hot for next year, a smudged and less precise eye makeup than we are used to wearing, […]
item.content:encoded:
What makeup trends will 2025 bring our way? We ae seeing lots of indications that a new version of 'skinification' will be in demand, a new and glowy minimalist approach to foundation.

Lived-in eye liner is also looking hot for next year, a smudged and less precise eye makeup than we are used to wearing, and colour will enter the equation alongside charcoal and black.

Today's top videos

Blush will remain a priority in beauty for another year, but the biggest trend will be for lips which is probably the most dramatic change of style in makeup trends than we have seen in a long time.

Makeup Trends 2025

The shift from black to coloured eyeliner has been coming through 2024, we have seen Victoria Beckham, Laura Mercier, Glossier and more issue liner and stick shadow/liners in sumptuous shades other than black and brown and long may it contiue.

Burgundy (like above) and jewel tones were as big a hit in beauty as they were in fashion, and it has been nice to play around with these colours in our makeup bags. But, when it came to our lip looks, we didn't really switch to anything more daring than a nude and a gloss. That is all about to change in 2025 because one of the biggest makeup trends is a new and trending lip colour - mocha lips.

Mocha Lips Trend

Pantone's Colour of the Year is Mocha Mousse and that probably is having a hand in boosting this makeup trend, but mocha tones were seen all over the New York Fashion shows for this season.

Hailey Bieber has been teasing a new brown lip liner for her Rhode brand on TikTok, we suspect she may have a bigger influence on making mocha lips one of the biggest makeup trends of the year. To get in on the trend early, this is what you need to buy.

Must-Have Lipstick

You won't need much to create this lip look. The best way to wear it is less like a picture-perfect lipstick and more like a stain and a little lived-in. Use lip liner to create shape and a slightly darker outline, but it doesn't need to be too perfect.

Matte and satin lipsticks are more edgy than high-shine, but if you find yourself lusting after a little gloss go with a clear shade to let those mocha lips shine through. As New Year makeup trends go, we are liking this move away from nude and pink-brown lips.

You Might Also Like

Six of the chicest Christmas makeup looks that will see you through to New Year's Eve

item.title: Review: We tried out the classic Christmas package at the Castlemartyr Resort
item.dc:creator: Lauren Walsh
item.description: Most people say that the only downside to holidaying in Ireland is the unpredictable weather, but this definitely doesn’t apply when staying at the Castlemartyr Resort. I visited Castlemartyr during one of the worst storms we have seen so far this winter, but the strong winds and heavy rain didn’t taint my experience even slightly. From […]
item.content:encoded:
Most people say that the only downside to holidaying in Ireland is the unpredictable weather, but this definitely doesn’t apply when staying at the Castlemartyr Resort.

I visited Castlemartyr during one of the worst storms we have seen so far this winter, but the strong winds and heavy rain didn’t taint my experience even slightly. From the moment you drive into the resort, you will be in for a trip of unparalleled opulence.

Today's top videos

The manicured grounds and sprawling estate are breathtaking, even under the stormiest of conditions.

Upon arrival, you can expect to be warmly greeted at reception with a glass of mulled wine and a towering, Kardashian-esque Christmas tree that immediately put me in the festive spirit. The good news is you can expect this unwaveringly high standard of service throughout the entirety of your trip.

The layout of the entire resort is extremely accessible, as the rooms, restaurants, and spa are on the ground floor, making it extremely suitable for any guests with mobility challenges.

The room 

To put it simply, the rooms at The Castlemartyr are breathtaking. It is probably reductive to even describe them as just ‘rooms’ as they are all essentially suites.

They come equipped with a large sit-down area, which features a desk to facilitate anyone who needs to work remotely, a king-sized bed, and a walk-in wardrobe. The rooms that I stayed in also boasted both a marble-covered bathroom and a smaller second toilet, with heated floors.

The room had everything we could have possibly needed, including a coffee machine, fully stocked with all of the necessary equipment. I made the corny joke that I could happily stay in the room for a week, but truth be told it probably wasn’t a joke at all!

Festive Afternoon Tea

The highlight of my stay was undoubtedly the Festive Afternoon Tea in Knight’s Bar. It was a truly magical experience. A harpist played gentle music that perfectly set the mood for the meal.

I was lucky enough to secure a table by the window, offering stunning views of the hotel's grounds. As we settled in, we were greeted with a glass of prosecco and given a menu showcasing an extensive selection of teas. 

Though I opted for a basic green tea, there was an extensive host of basic green tea, there was an extensive host of options (most of which I hadn't heard of!) After placing my (admittedly easy) order, we were treated to a delectable parfait dish to start. 

Then came the main event, a three-tiered stand brimming with freshly baked treats. The bottom tier featured a delightful assortment of finger sandwiches, including Ballycotton smoked salmon on homemade brown bread, while the middle tier held warm, freshly baked scones both plain and fruit.

If you still have room after that, the top tier is filled with an array of exquisite sweet treats prepared by the resort’s talented pastry chef.

Between the harp, the festive sparkle of the Christmas décor, and the homemade delights, I would highly recommend the Festive Afternoon Tea at Castlemartyr to anyone looking for a memorable experience this season. 

The Service 

After tea, we returned to our room, where we found that the complimentary water from our arrival had already been replenished- a small but thoughtful touch.

This is a good time to point out that the staff at The Castlemartyr were incredibly attentive and helpful throughout my stay, always eager to assist with anything I needed.

Whether I was asking for directions or passing them in the hallway, they always greeted me with a warm smile and a willingness to go the extra mile. You can expect service of the highest standard when staying at the resort.

Pre-Dinner Drinks at Knight’s Bar 

There is always something to do while staying at the hotel. If you are looking for a pre-dinner drink, then the Victorian-style Knight’s Bar is the place to be.

The cocktail menu was filled with unique concoctions specific to the resort, as well as some classics. I decided to branch out and chose a lavender-infused cocktail, garnished with purple petals, which was both delicious and beautifully presented.

Dining Canopy Restaurant

From there, we made our way to the Canopy Restaurant, where the staff graciously carried my unfinished drink to the restaurant for me. Despite the restaurant being quite full, the tables were spaced out in such a way that it felt peaceful and intimate. 

The room had large glass walls which provided views of the resort’s grounds, emphasising the restaurant’s already tranquil ambiance. The festive menu offered a wide variety of choices. 

I started with the smoked salmon starter, which arrived in a generous portion with pickled shallots and capers. 

For my main course, I opted for the Wicklow venison loin, which was served alongside a melt-in-your-mouth braised shoulder of venison. Once again, the staff were exemplary, ensuring our glasses were never empty and making sure we had everything we needed. 

Each time I took a sip from my wine glass, it was swiftly refilled- both a blessing and, perhaps, a curse!

After dinner, the doors to the Canopy Brasserie were opened, where a live band was playing light jazz accompanied by a singer. The perfect end to a perfect evening!

Breakfast 

The Canopy Restaurant totally transforms to cater to the breakfast buffet.

If you are fond of a hotel breakfast (who isn't?) you will be thrilled to see that there are both à la carte and buffet options available. I opted for French toast and a latte, and once again the meal was delicious.

I cannot fault my stay at The Castlemartyr Resort in any way. The decor was gorgeous, the food and drinks were second to none, and most notably, the staff was exemplary. If you are hoping for a regal night away, it is definitely the place for you.

You can secure a night in the junior suite for €352, meanwhile, a stay in the deluxe room will cost €275. If you would like to experience a stay at the resort for yourself, please visit their website here.

item.title: Eight things they don't tell you about working in Dunnes at Christmas
item.dc:creator: Anna Martin
item.description: I have been on both sides when it comes to the Christmas dash to get the shopping done. I have been the stressed-out customer and the stressed-out Dunnes worker. Let me tell you that working in retail at Christmas gives you a whole new appreciation for the person scanning your €10 off €50 shopping vouchers. […]
item.content:encoded:
I have been on both sides when it comes to the Christmas dash to get the shopping done. I have been the stressed-out customer and the stressed-out Dunnes worker.

Let me tell you that working in retail at Christmas gives you a whole new appreciation for the person scanning your €10 off €50 shopping vouchers.

Today's top videos

Things are bad enough when you see your 70th smoked ham make its way down the till, but then throw in the shop being open for 24 hours and you're two steps away from becoming Scrooge.

Here are eight things people don't tell you about working in Dunnes at Christmas and before you ask, no, I don't know what comes in the Christmas crackers, read the back of the box.

Queue related anxiety

On my way to Dunnes on the Childers Road pic.twitter.com/3dj90LE7RX

— Kathryn (@whatkathryn) December 22, 2022

I know, I know, standing in line with your trolly full and the panic of trying to get home to make dinner is awful for any customer but I want you to flip it for two seconds.

When sitting in that chair behind the till and you turn your head and see a queue that goes all the way to the frozen aisle there is this brief moment when you start to feel like a hamster trapped on one of those wheels.

Stuck doing the same action over and over scanning back and forth, do you have a Clubcard, or any vouchers? It starts to feel like a slow and never-ending descent into madness.

As folks battle their way to get into the shops, judging by the mad pictures of queues doing the rounds on Twitter, the staff on the inside are also fighting a mental battle to make sure they make it out alive at the end of their shift.

Flocks of turkeys

Yes I mean flocks. We've seen every form of the bird you can imagine, the crown, whole, boned and rolled, stuffed, you name it and it has been scanned at some point in the day.

It gets to a point where you begin to question do you even want a turkey for Christmas, just the mere sight of the winged beast gives you flashbacks to arguing over the price of a two-kilogram bird with Mary from up the road.

Ungodly amounts of cheese

Let me start this by saying I love cheese as much as the next lactose intolerant person but I had never seen so much of it before I worked Christmas in Dunnes.

I had no idea how important it is to Christmas, I could even argue now that it could be put above the turkey due to the sheer volume I encountered that fateful year.

Blocks, boards, wheels, you name it and I've scanned it. To this day I would argue that I have a better knowledge of cheese varieties than the average person.

24 hours of pain

Okay I get it I really do, the shop being open 24 hours is fantastic for busy parents trying to balance getting the food shop done on top of their regular 9-5.

Now my issue is when everyone in the country thinks they have this amazing idea of rocking up at 6am to get their shopping. In theory it's great, in practice not so much.

The queue is no longer contained within the shop, it's out the door, customers are frozen, we're frozen from the open doors and no one is happy.

There are these brief moments during the 24 hours when things go quiet but don't you dare say it out loud, we all know that as soon as someone says the words "ah it's not too bad now" an influx of enough people to fill the Aviva will poor in the doors so relish the moment in silence, please.

Terrified temps

They usually come in so young and full of hope. Just give it a few days and you'll see their spirits start to break as yet another auld wan gives out to them for not being fast enough.

Their wide-eyed excitement soon turns to thinly veiled terror as they try and keep it together when yet another voucher is out of date. If you see one of these children in uniform, please be nice, they're trying their best like the rest of us.

Bag packer solidarity

We are there for each other the bag packers and the staff, there is an unspoken bond that we share. When things get tough you can vent to the charity worker at the end of your till, honestly they should be paid as therapists.

Not only do they listen to you but they listen to the customer, if Sue is wound up about something the person with the bucket is always there to help calm things down.

We salute you guys.

Older staff are saviours

When you work your first job in retail it can be scary, especially during the Christmas period. It sometimes feels like you can never get anything right, you're overwhelmed and have been shouted at three times within the first hour.

As the tears build up in your eyes, you see a bright light coming towards you. It's Bernie who has been working here 20 odd years and she has a tin of sweets in her hands.

Older staff are always there with advice to pick you up when you feel like the world is ending, they're knights in shining armour, the only difference is they don't have swords, just a key to open the till when you give the wrong change.

The unscannable voucher

So you've checked the date seven or eight times, flattened it out and tried over and over yet you're still not hearing the beep. The customer looks annoyed and your hands are sweating only making things worse.

Any jokes you crack aren't lightening the mood and the queue behind is only getting longer. It's time to start praying that your manager can fix whatever is happening down on till number five and will come save you before you run out of the shop and never come back.

You Might Also Like

Basically triplets! Rosanna Davison's kids match adorably in Dunnes Christmas jumpers (and they're still available)
